IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8602 S1381-1169(12)00393-7 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.11.021 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 XRD patterns of the synthesized catalysts (a) CuO/A, (b) CuO/A7R3, (c) CuO/A3R7, and (d) CuO/R. The letters A and R indicate anatase and rutile crystalline phases of TiO2. Fig. 2 HR-TEM images of the synthesized catalysts (A and B) CuO/A, and (C–E) CuO/R. The inset shows FT images of the CuO/A catalyst. Fig. 3 EPR spectra of the synthesized catalysts (a) CuO/A, (b) CuO/A7R3, (c) CuO/A3R7, and (d) CuO/R. Fig. 4 TPR profiles of the synthesized catalysts (a) CuO/A, (b) CuO/A7R3, (c) CuO/A3R7, and (d) CuO/R. P1-1 and P1-2 show the reduction of Cu2+ →Cu1+ and Cu1+ →Cu0, respectively. P2 exhibits the reduction of anatase TiO2. Fig. 5 Cu 2p XPS spectra of the synthesized catalysts (A) CuO/A, (B) CuO/A7R3, (C) CuO/A3R7, and (D) CuO/R. Deconvoluted peaks represented as dotted lines (Cu0and Cu1+), dash line (Cu2+), and solid lines (Cus) species. Fig. 6 Relationship between binding energy (■) and surface atomic ratio of Cu2+ species (□) with changes in the composition of rutile phase. Fig. 7 Catalytic activities of the synthesized catalysts for the oxidation of CO for CuO/A (•), CuO/A7R3 (○), CuO/A3R7 (□), and CuO/R (■). Table 1 TPR data for the synthesized catalysts. TPR Peak1-1 Peak1-2 Peak2 Temp. (°C) Area (a.u.) Temp. (°C) Area (a.u.) Temp. (°C) Area (a.u.) CuO/R 113 18 – – – – CuO/A3R7 119 13 130 4 463 20 CuO/A7R3 131 10 148 6 468 51 CuO/A 140 9 155 7 474 60 Effect of TiO2 crystalline phase on CO oxidation over CuO catalysts supported on TiO2 Mi Yeong Kang 1 Hyeong Jin Yun 1 Sungju Yu Wooyoung Kim Nam Dong Kim Jongheop Yi ⁎ World Class University (WCU) Program of Chemical Convergence for Energy and Environment (C2E2), Institute of Chemical Processes, School of Chemical and Biological Engineering, College of Engineering, Seoul National University (SNU), Seoul 151-742, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 880 7438. 1 Mi Yeong Kang and Hyeong Jin Yun contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Highlights ► CuO/TiO2 catalysts with various compositions of anatase and rutile are prepared. ► The type of TiO2 phase affects the catalytic properties of the CuO catalysts. ► CuO/R provides large amounts of oxygen atoms for reaction with CO. ► The activities of CuO/TiO2 decrease with the decrease in amounts of rutile phase. CuO catalysts supported on TiO2 with various compositions of anatase and rutile phase (CuO/R, CuOR7A3, CuOR3A7 and CuO/A) are prepared by a deposition–precipitation procedure, and products are characterized using EPR, TPR, and XPS. The oxidation of CO is used as a model reaction case to test for catalytic activity. Importantly, the type of TiO2 phase present has an effect on the physical, chemical, and catalytic properties of the CuO catalysts. The rutile phase of the TiO2 support (CuO/R) interacts weakly with the CuO and TiO2 support. Cu2+ ions in the supported-CuO are readily reduced to Cu0 during the CO oxidation reaction. Consequently, CuO/R provides large amounts of oxygen atoms for reaction with CO, which results in the highest catalytic activity among the catalysts examined. The activities of supported CuO catalysts decrease gradually with the decrease in amounts of rutile phase. Keywords Anatase Rutile TiO2 CuO CO oxidation 1 Introduction Titanium oxide (TiO2) is considered to be a promising material for use in various catalytic processes, particularly as a catalyst support [1–4]. Fine metal nanoparticles supported on TiO2 exhibit a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [5]. Thus, metal nanoparticles on TiO2 support formed under the SMSI conditions are remarkably stable with high dispersion even at elevated temperature. Because such catalysts contain an increased number of active sites and interactions between the metal and support are enhanced, their catalytic activities can be improved considerably. TiO2 is mainly classified into anatase, rutile and brookite phases, based on its crystalline structure. Anatase and rutile TiO2 are generally used as engineering materials more frequently than the brookite form and many studies have been reported on the synthesis and catalytic applications of anatase and rutile phases. The surface, physical, chemical, and structural properties of these phases are different from other phases. Anatase TiO2 particles are typically less than 50nm in size and they tend to become adsorbed easily to organic compounds. Rutile TiO2 particles are generally larger than 200nm and are more thermodynamically stable than anatase TiO2 [6]. Several studies have previously reported in the influence of TiO2 crystalline phases on photo-catalytic applications [7–9]. These studies claim that the different photo-catalytic performances of the two phases can mainly be attributed to differences in the probability of charge recombination, band-gap energy, and the adsorptive affinity between anatase and rutile TiO2 [10]. In addition, it was recently reported that the efficiencies of TiO2-supported catalysts were also dependent on various crystalline phases in several catalytic processes [11]. Fan et al. reported that anatase TiO2-supported palladium catalysts showed a higher activity than rutile TiO2-supported catalysts in selective hydrogenation reactions, due to the superior SMSI behavior of anatase TiO2 [12]. Nguyen et al. also reported that the catalytic activity of gold supported on anatase TiO2 was superior to other catalysts examined for the reduction of NO x by propene because of the smaller size of the gold particles on anatase TiO2 [13]. In spite of the various studies cited above, their primary focus was on the influence of the TiO2 crystalline phases themselves on catalytic reactions, and the effects of changes in the deposited metals/metal oxides were largely ignored. It is estimated that various TiO2 crystalline phases as supports can affect the SMSI [2], electronic density, oxidation state, metal size [4], and metal dispersion [11] of the deposited material. These changes in deposited metals/metal oxides on the different phases of crystalline TiO2 can have a dramatic impact on catalytic performance. Therefore a better understanding of how various TiO2 phases effect changes in the physical and chemical properties of supported metals/metal oxides would be highly desirable. In order to address this issue, we designed a series of supports that contained various combinations of crystalline phases of anatase and rutile TiO2. Various TiO2-supported catalysts such as Pd/TiO2 [1], AuTiO2 [4], Pt/TiO2 [11], and Co/TiO2 [14] have previously been developed for numerous industrial applications such as, the hydrosulfurization of hydrocarbon oils [3], the epoxidation of propene [15], and the selective catalytic reduction of NO x [16], to name a few examples. Among the diverse catalytic processes, the oxidation of CO is a representative and potentially important application. This reaction involves minimal side-reactions and mild reaction conditions. In general, it is carried out at ranging from room temperature to 300°C under atmospheric pressure. Moreover this reaction has recently attracted considerable interest for preventing the poisoning of Pt catalysts by CO in proton exchange membrane fuel cell systems [17]. It has been reported that copper oxide (CuO) catalysts are highly active for CO oxidation [10,18]. CuO has additional advantages such as a high thermal stability and the fact that it is economical. In this study, CuO/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized by a deposition–precipitation method. Small amounts of CuO were then loaded on TiO2 and the influence of the TiO2 crystalline phase on the efficiency of CO oxidation was examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Various TiO2 supports with different crystalline compositions were prepared by physically mixing pure anatase and rutile TiO2. The anatase TiO2 support was synthesized using a previously reported gel–sol method [19,20]. Titanium tetraisopropoxide (Advanced Materials Institute Co. Ltd., 98%) as the Ti precursor, triethanolamine (Sigma, 98%, a gelation agent) and oleic acid (Samchun, 99.9%) were dissolved in 60ml deionized water. This mixture was transferred to Teflon-lined autoclave at 100°C for 12h then heated at 250°C for 48h, resulting in the formation of a TiO2 precipitate. This slurry was dried at 80°C for 12h after several centrifugations. The rutile TiO2 support was prepared by direct calcination of commercial TiO2 (P25, Degussa) at 800°C for 6h. TiO2 supports with different crystalline compositions were prepared by physically mixing anatase and rutile phases of TiO2 in ratios of 10:0, 7:3, 3:7 and 0:10. CuO/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized via a deposition–precipitation (DP) method. The DP process is a reliable and effective method which results in the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles on the support. This method is widely used in preparing nanosized noble metal catalysts, such as supported Au-, Pt-, Ru-based catalysts [21,22]. In the present study, we attempted to deposit CuO on the nanoparticles so as to produce a non-noble metal oxide catalyst. In order to achieve a metal oxide loading of 1wt.% on the support, portions of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O (Aldrich) (a CuO precursor) were dissolved in 100ml of deionized water. This metal salt solution was adjusted to pH of 8 with 0.1M NaOH. After the formation of copper precipitates after 2h, 1g of the TiO2 support was added to this solution, which was then heated to 70°C and allowed to age for 2h. This mixture was washed with 1L deionized water and dried at 80°C for 12h. The resulting powder was calcined at 300°C for 4h in an atmosphere of air. The CuO catalysts supported on TiO2 are denoted as CuO/A, CuO/A7R3, CuO/A3R7, and CuO/R, based on the ratio of anatase (A) and rutile (R) TiO2. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The crystalline phases of the catalysts were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/max-2500/PC, Rigaku) using Cu Kα radiation (wavelength=0.154nm) as an incident beam at 50kV and 100mA. The BET surface area of the samples was determined by nitrogen adsorption at – 196°C using a Micromeritics ASAP-2010 system. The microstructures were examined by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, JEM3010, JEOL, 300kV). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were collected at 123K under an atmosphere of nitrogen (JES-TE200, JEOL). The reducing characteristics of the catalysts were examined by means of temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements. These analyses were carried out using a 100mg sample and a temperature ramp to 500°C at 5°C/min. A mixture of 10vol.% H2 in N2 was used as the reducing agent and was introduced at a flow rate of 50ml/min. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used to detect the amount of H2 consumed during the analysis. A gas chromatograph (M600D, Young Lin) was used to analyze the outlet gas. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted to investigate the oxidation states and elemental compositions of the catalysts (AXIS-His, KRATOS). Binding energies were calibrated with respect to C 1s (285eV). A 1253.6eV X-ray source, using a Mg Ka anode at 450W, was employed. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic CO oxidations were performed to determine the activities of the catalysts. The sample (100mg) was then charged into a quartz tube reactor. The total flow rate of the reaction feed was 50ml/min at gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) with 30,000mlh/g and consisted of CO/O2 with a molar ratio of 1/1 in He. This reaction was conducted from 35°C to 300°C with heating rate of 0.5°C/min. All experiments were carried out at atmospheric pressure. The reaction products were determined by gas chromatography (Young Lin 6000 series), which was equipped with a TCD gas detector. The catalytic activities were calculated by CO consumption in the effluent and indicated as CO conversion followed by: (1) CO conversion ( % ) = [ CO ] i n − [ CO ] o u t [ CO ] i n × 100 3 Results and discussion In this study, highly dispersed CuO particles on TiO2 supports were prepared with various crystalline compositions. Fig. 1 shows XRD patterns of the designed catalysts. The characteristic peaks for anatase TiO2 were detected at 25.3° (101), 37.8° (004), and 48.0° (200). The characteristic XRD signals for rutile TiO2 appear at 2θ =27.4° (110), 36.1° (101), and 54.3° (211). The crystalline sizes of anatase and rutile TiO2 are approximately estimated by using the Sherrer's equation from XRD results, as follows [23]: (2) σ = 0.9 λ β cos θ where σ is the crystalline size, λ is the X-ray wavelength, β is the line broadening at half the maximum intensity (FWHM) in radians, and θ is the Bragg angle. The crystalline sizes of anatase and rutile TiO2 are estimated to be 27.3nm and 54.3nm, respectively. The characteristics of the diffraction patterns are dependent on the composition of the two phase components. The typical peak intensities of rutile TiO2 tend to increase gradually with increasing ratio of rutile TiO2. To accurately determine the phase compositions of anatase and rutile TiO2, Spur and Meyer's equation was used, as follows [8]: (3) % R u t i l e = 1 ( A / R ) × 0.884 + 1 × 100 where A and R are the area for the major peaks for the anatase (2θ =25.3°) and rutile phases (2θ =27.4°), respectively. The number 0.884 is a scattering coefficient [24]. The calculated composition of the rutile phase is denoted as Rx (x %) in Fig. 1 and is in good agreement with the mixtures of anatase and rutile phases in the designed TiO2. The characteristic XRD peak for CuO in the synthesized catalysts was not found at 35.5° indicating a (110) plane. This suggests that the deposited CuO nanoparticles are too small to permit their detection by XRD. Thus, highly dispersed CuO nanoparticles were successfully formed on the TiO2 support using the DP method. In addition, BET surface areas for prepared samples were measured. The surface areas for CuO/A, CuO/A7R3, CuO/A3R7, and CuO/R are decreased with the increase in the fraction of rutile phase of TiO2 as 95.20m2/g, 75.56m2/g, 34.97m2/g, and 11.96m2/g, respectively. Representative HR-TEM images of CuO/A and CuO/R catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . The particle sizes of the anatase and rutile TiO2 clusters are approximately 27.4±6.0nm and 161.7±27.6nm, respectively. It is difficult to directly measure the sizes of CuO nanoparticles on anatase TiO2, due to the similarity of their sizes, which makes distinguishing CuO from TiO2 difficult. A Fourier transform (FT) method was used in order to gain further insights into the nature of the deposited CuO. Fig. 2(B) shows FT images of the CuO/A catalyst. While the lattice fringes of anatase TiO2 emerge at 3.5Å and are assigned to a (101) plane [15], CuO shows a d-spacing at 2.5Å, which can be attributed to the presence of a (−110) plane [25]. The CuO/A catalyst exhibits two distinct crystallite planes corresponding to the lattice fringes of anatase TiO2 and CuO in Fig. 2(B). Thus, FT images confirm that CuO particles are, in fact, deposited on the anatase TiO2. As shown in Fig. 2(C)–(E), CuO nanoparticles with uniform sizes are highly dispersed on the rutile TiO2. They resemble pseudo-spheres with an average diameter of approximately 15.9±3.7nm. It should be noted that CuO nanoparticles, a non-noble metal oxide, can be readily deposited on a TiO2 support with a high degree of dispersion and uniform sizes via the DP method. Several theoretical studies have estimated the stability of the rutile TiO2 (110) surface and the different low-index anatase TiO2 [26,27]. The findings indicate that the surface formation energy for rutile TiO2 (110) is 0.31J/m2, which is a relatively low value compared to anatase surfaces [(110) – 0.44, (100) – 0.53, (001) – 0.90 and (110) – 1.09J/m2) [26,27]. This indicates that the surface of the rutile TiO2 is more stable than that of the anatase used in this study. The differences in the surface stability of anatase and rutile TiO2 can affect the electronic state of copper oxide, consequently catalytic performance in the oxidation of CO. The relation between the electronic state of the catalysts and oxidative catalytic performance was investigated in EPR, TPR, and XPS experiments. EPR is a useful technique for obtaining information on the electronic structure of such catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3 , two signals for g values are observed, which are attributed to the presence of Ti3+ ions (3d1) [1]. Ti3+ species are produced by the trapping of electrons at defective sites in TiO2, and the amount of accumulated electrons may, therefore, reflect the number of defective sites present in the catalysts [28]. The signals for g ⊥ =1.973 and g || =1.934 can be attributed to electrons that are trapped in Ti3+ sites [12,29]. Interestingly peaks corresponding to Ti3+ ions in the CuO/A catalyst are abundant, compared to the other synthesized catalysts. With a decrease in anatase TiO2 content, the peak intensities of Ti3+ ions also tend to decrease. In the case of the pure rutile TiO2-supported catalyst, CuO/R, no Ti3+ EPR signal can be detected. Very low levels of Ti3+ species are formed by the trapping of electrons in rutile TiO2, given their thermodynamic and structural stabilities. It is well known that titanium ions can be strongly stabilized by forming a Ti4+ oxidation state. Thus, the formation of Ti3+ ions can be assumed to represent an unstable state, which can have a significant effect on the crystalline and interfacial region of TiO2 between the deposited CuO and the TiO2 support. The characteristic reducibility of the catalysts was determined via TPR measurements. Fig. 4 shows the reduction profiles for the synthesized catalysts. The TPR signals indicate that the main reduction peaks appear at around 140°C and 470°C. The peak for the low temperature range from 100°C to 200°C can be deconvoluted into two peaks that correspond to the stepwise reduction of CuO [30]. Among the two deconvoluted peaks, the lower temperature peak corresponds to the reduction of Cu2+ (P1-1) and the peak at a relatively high temperature is assigned to the reduction of Cu1+ to Cu0 (P1-2) [17]. For further analysis, the reduction temperatures and peak areas are summarized in Table 1 . In a relatively low temperature range of less than 140°C, Cu2+ is mainly reduced to Cu0 but also is partially reduced to the Cu1+ state. While the CuO of the CuO/R catalyst is directly reduced from Cu2+ to Cu0, in the case of the anatase TiO2-supported catalysts, CuO/A, CuO/A7R3, and CuO/A3R7, stepwise reduction of Cu2+ and Cu1+ occurs, indicating the presence of Cu1+ species in the anatase TiO2-supported catalysts. Cu1+ species are formed by interactions with unstable Ti3+ ions which tend to produce a stable structure. As shown by the EPR analyses, rutile TiO2 is thermodynamically and structurally stable, while in the case of anatase TiO2, large amounts of unstable Ti3+ ions are produced on the surface lattice. The unstable Ti3+ species in anatase TiO2 can readily diffuse to the interface between CuO and TiO2 [12]. These behaviors are less prominent with increasing amount of rutile TiO2. Thus the CuO of the CuO/R catalyst is easily reduced compared to anatase TiO2-supported catalysts, which involve a two-step reduction of CuO. The findings indicate that the CuO reduction peaks tend to shift to a lower temperature range with increasing amounts of rutile TiO2. In the CuO/A catalyst, CuO begins to be reduced at a higher temperature (125°C) compared to the CuO/R catalyst (100°C). The shift in the reduction peaks can be attributed to the effect of anatase and rutile phases on the reducibility of CuO. In other words, these peak shifts suggest that the reducibility of CuO is affected by their interaction with the TiO2 support as well as the surface properties of anatase and rutile TiO2. The catalysts that contain large amounts of rutile TiO2 are easily reduced at lower temperatures. The easy reduction of Cu2+ on rutile TiO2 indicates that surface oxygen is more easily released from the CuO than that from anatase TiO2. This can be attributed to differences in the interactions between CuO and rutile or anatase TiO2. This provides helpful information on the contribution of Ti3+ species to the characteristics of anatase TiO2, in which a strong interaction appears to be ongoing between CuO and anatase TiO2. At high temperatures, above 400°C, the anatase TiO2-supported catalysts exhibit a peak that can be assigned to the reduction of anatase TiO2 [31] . It appears that Ti4+ and Ti3+ species in the relatively unstable structure of anatase TiO2 are reduced more easily at high temperatures than rutile TiO2. The consumption of hydrogen decreased with increasing amounts of rutile TiO2 in the catalysts. In the case of the pure rutile TiO2-supported catalyst, CuO/R, no phase transformation was observed, even at a high temperature of over 400°C, which suggests that pure rutile TiO2 does not have any significant reducible properties due to its thermal and structural stability. XPS analyses were conducted to investigate the effect of the TiO2 crystalline phases on the oxidation states and elemental ratios of surface copper ions. Fig. 5 shows XPS data for the Cu 2p3/2 core level for each sample. The spectra were deconvoluted into three pairs of peaks with binding energies of 932.3, 934.0 and 942.0eV, which were assigned to reduced copper species (Cu0 and Cu1+), fully oxidized copper species (Cu2+), and shakeup satellite peaks (Cus), respectively [32]. It has been reported that it is difficult to distinguish between the values for the binding energy of Cu0 and Cu1+ species from XPS data (932.1–932.5eV) [33]. Here, we assumed that the peak at 932.3eV is a deconvoluted peak related to Cu0 and Cu1+ species. The values of 934.0 and 942.0eV are attributed to the obvious existence of fully oxidized CuO [7]. For the CuO/A catalyst, the presence of Cu0 and Cu1+ species (76%) is dominant. These peak intensities decrease with decreasing ratios of anatase TiO2. In particular, a large amount of Cu2+ species is present in the CuO/R catalyst (82%). It should be noted that the ratio of Cu2+ species changes with various compositions of anatase and rutile phase. This is in good agreement with the EPR and TPR results, in which the amount of reduced CuO on rutile TiO2 is larger than that for anatase TiO2. This can be attributed to Ti3+ species, which are associated with the surface lattice of anatase TiO2 and easily diffuses to the surface of CuO particles and interact with the oxygen in CuO. As a result, small amounts of Cu2+ species are present on the anatase TiO2 because the unstable Ti3+ ions are susceptible to oxidation, to form a stable state. Interestingly, the peak related to the Cu2+ state shifts to lower binding energy with increasing rutile TiO2 composition. This indicates that Cu2+ species are present in a highly dispersed state on rutile TiO2, a conclusion that is consistent with the TEM results. It is known that highly dispersed Cu2+ species have a lower binding energy than bulk Cu2+ in CuO [7]. As shown in Fig. 6 , the CuO/A catalyst exhibited a relatively high binding energy that is induced by strong interactions between CuO and anatase TiO2. The above results suggest that unstable Ti3+ ions in anatase TiO2 tend to interact strongly with CuO, thus reaching a more stable state. The peak shifts to a lower binding energy with increasing composition of rutile phase imply that interactions of CuO bond in CuO/R catalysts are weaker than in the CuO/A catalyst [34]. To investigate the catalytic behaviors of the prepared catalysts, the catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide was studied in the temperature range from 50°C to 300°C and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The CuO/R catalyst showed the best reactivity for the catalytic oxidation of CO, providing a total CO oxidation over 170°C. As the composition of rutile TiO2 decreased, the catalytic activities for CO oxidation also decreased gradually. The CuO/A catalyst showed a 72% CO conversion at 300°C. In addition, the reaction temperature for the total CO oxidation over the synthesized catalysts shifted to a higher temperature range with increasing anatase TiO2 content. The catalytic oxidation of CO over the CuO/TiO2 catalysts involves a reaction with oxygen in the CuO and TiO2 support [35]. The higher catalytic oxidation performance of the CuO/R catalysts indicate that lattice oxygen in the finely dispersed CuO on rutile TiO2 can readily participate in the oxidation of CO. The CuO/R catalyst contains a large amount of Cu2+ oxidation state which can be readily reduced to the Cu0 state. Thus, it has the capability to provide a large amount of oxygen from its own lattice during oxidation reaction, which accounts for its exceptional catalytic performance. On the other hand, unstable Ti3+ species in anatase TiO2 would be expected to diffuse and interact with lattice oxygen in CuO. Thus, lattice oxygen in the CuO on anatase TiO2 cannot participate efficiently in CO oxidation up to a relatively high temperature, because of the strong interactions between CuO and anatase TiO2 compared to rutile TiO2-supported catalysts. The above findings provide an explanation for how various crystalline phases of TiO2 affect the catalytic behavior CuO/TiO2 catalysts in the oxidation of CO. 4 Conclusions Highly dispersed CuO nanoparticles were prepared on different TiO2 supports containing various compositions of crystalline phase by a deposition–precipitation method. The findings show that various crystalline compositions of anatase and rutile TiO2 can affect the chemical and physical properties of supported CuO nanoparticles. TEM, EPR, TPR, and XPS measurements revealed the existence of remarkable changes in the degree of CuO dispersion, interactions between CuO and the TiO2 support, and subsequently, the oxidation states of copper ions in the preparations. The CuO/R catalyst showed the highest activity for CO oxidation. The thermodynamically and structurally stable CuO/R catalyst was found to react readily with CO due to the high dispersion and weak interactions between CuO and the TiO2 support. The catalytic performances of the prepared samples tend to be gradually reduced with decreasing composition of rutile phase. The CuO catalyst supported on anatase TiO2, in which strong interactions exist, suffers from low activity for CO oxidation at lower temperatures. Consequently, the findings herein demonstrate that the catalytic oxidation of CO over CuO/TiO2 catalysts is strongly influenced by the composition of the anatase and rutile phases in the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: CuO catalysts supported on TiO2 with various compositions of anatase and rutile phase (CuO/R, CuOR7A3, CuOR3A7 and CuO/A) are prepared by a deposition–precipitation procedure, and products are characterized using EPR, TPR, and XPS. The oxidation of CO is used as a model reaction case to test for catalytic activity. Importantly, the type of TiO2 phase present has an effect on the physical, chemical, and catalytic properties of the CuO catalysts. The rutile phase of the TiO2 support (CuO/R) interacts weakly with the CuO and TiO2 support. Cu2+ ions in the supported-CuO are readily reduced to Cu0 during the CO oxidation reaction. Consequently, CuO/R provides large amounts of oxygen atoms for reaction with CO, which results in the highest catalytic activity among the catalysts examined. The activities of supported CuO catalysts decrease gradually with the decrease in amounts of rutile phase.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of TiO2 crystalline phase on CO oxidation over CuO catalysts supported on TiO2
